hotspots.label: Spider's Long Legs
hotspots.fact: Spiders have eight long, thin legs that help them move quickly and sense their environment. These legs are covered with tiny hairs that can feel vibrations in the air and on the ground, helping the spider find food and stay safe from danger.

vocabulary.definition: Body parts that stick out from an animal's body, like legs, arms, or antennae, that help it move and interact with the world.

hotspots.label: Spider's Body Parts
hotspots.fact: A spider's body has two main sections: the head and body combined (called the cephalothorax) and the back section (called the abdomen). Different body parts help the spider do important jobs like seeing, eating, and making silk for webs.

vocabulary.definition: The different parts that make up an animal's body and how they work together to help the animal survive and do activities.

hotspots.label: Spider as a Predator
hotspots.fact: Spiders are hunters that catch insects for food, which makes them important members of ecosystems. By eating insects, spiders help control insect populations and keep nature balanced, showing how different living things depend on each other.

vocabulary.definition: An animal that hunts and eats other animals to survive.

hotspots.label: Spider's Eyes
hotspots.fact: Most spiders have multiple eyes, usually eight, that help them see movement and find prey. Spider eyes are very good at detecting when something is moving nearby, which helps them survive in their habitat.

vocabulary.definition: Special body parts that help animals sense and learn about their surroundings, like eyes for seeing and ears for hearing.
